Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this project is to develop non-toxic nanocontainers loaded with corrosion inhibitors so they can be admixed to paint. To protect metals from corrosion (ships, industrial machines, petroleum platforms) one admixes into coating paint chemicals called corrosion inhibitors. However, these protective additives are easily washed out or decomposed (especially in sea water) and metal surfaces become rusted. The idea of this project is to load corrosion inhibitors into tiny containers, nanometer size tubes, and to close tube ends with stoppers. These inhibitor loaded nanotubes can be admixed to paint. Corrosion inhibitors will stay inside these nanotubes for months and years, and will be released in the coating defects providing corrosion healing. Corrosion of metals is a serious problem: $280 billion is spent annually for corrosion damage repair and protection in USA alone, and a variety of methods have been developed to overcome it. One of the disadvantages of inorganic inhibitors is their toxicity; for example, widely used chromates are proven to cause cancer and are recently forbidden. Nanocontainers to be developed in this project are halloysite clay nanotubes with length 800 nm and diameter 50 nm. Halloysite is an environmentally friendly nanomaterial; it is mined from natural deposits in thousand tons and is not toxic.

An introduction of environmentally friendly organic inhibitor nanocontainers for protective coatings is very important. Additionally to scientific development, the two outreach tasks will be performed: the project will employ undergraduate researchers from Grambling State University, a Historically Black university; and, through contacts with K-12 schools, science teachers and students will be taught about nanomaterials, including simple experiments with anticorrosion coating based on loaded halloysite clay.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Often, when people hear the term nanotechnology they think about expensive and exotic materials that defy conventional knowledge. Not many would imagine that the clay we find in dirt would be a valuable and environmentally friendly nanomaterial. In this project we studied flat sheets of clay named kaolin that have been rolled, by a natural process, into empty tubes with a diameter of 50 nm. These tubes are called halloysite nanotubes, and are so small that they are 1000 times thinner than hair.

By adding these nanotubes to paint and other polymers we observed that the strength of the polymer doubled. This effect can be explained by the observation that halloysite tube network acts like “skeleton” in bulk polymers.   Furthermore, because the tubes are empty we can fill them with interesting molecules that serve some purpose. Then, because of the very narrow- nanoscale sized - opening of the tube, the molecules leak out slowly over time (adjusted for days and months). The combination of these two characteristics allowed for the creation of corrosion resistant / self-healing paints for metallic objects and flame resistant polymer composites. For this halloysite nanotubes loaded with corrosion inhibitors or flame-retardant phosphates were admixed at 5 % to polymers or paint. The metal protective nanocoating is especially needed for work in extreme conditions needed, such as oil drilling in ocean depth. We patented the technique of “smart protective coating” using halloysite loaded with functional chemicals and have received much industrial interest in various application of the technology.

A major facet of this work is finding ways to exploit the extended release of molecules from halloysite nanotubes. In this spirit, we experimented with many different functional compaunds and observed a variety of interesting outcomes. Halloysite is an efficient carrier for antibacterial molecules and drugs and may be developed for spray antiseptic coatings in hospitals to aid in the fight against superbugs (even simple iodine loaded into clay nanotubes works much more efficient, killing bacteria during many hours). Halloysite was also shown to be an excellent carrier for catalytic metal nanoparticles selectively located inside or outside the tubes and may greatly improve the efficiency of related technologies, such as exhaust catalytic converters in vehicles efficient at very high temperatures.

As expected, nano-safety is an integral part of our research. We believe that technologies based on clay nanomaterials offer an environmentally friendly alternative to synthetic technologies, and we predict that in time we will see the incorporation of green nanomaterials, such as our clay, into household technologies. Halloysite is abundant natural nanomaterial available in thousand tons at low price for industrial applications.
